Other age details or opinions: The Guanal likely appears into the Wisconsinin and might extend earlier than the Wisconsinin, i.e. into the lower Late or even Middle Pleistocene.
Correlation: Cocodrilo overlies and laterally grades into the Guanal. Cerro Caudal also overlies Guanal. Implied correlation between the Cocodrilo and the La Cabana and Salado fms (Castellanos et al 2003, Castellanos 2011).

Other age details or opinions: Franco's correlation of Santa Isabel with the La Cabana would suggest Wisconsinin (late Upper Pleistocene)

Notes: Castellanos 2011 considered the unit a fm rather than mbr of Cayo Piedras
Other age details or opinions: Castellanos (2011) plotted Cocodrilo fm as late Upper Pleistocene. See notes for Cayo Piedras in this correlation.
Correlation: Correlated with La Cabana, Versalles, and Lopez Orta fms. Santa Isabel grades laterally into Cerro Caudal mbr. Cocodrilo overlies and laterally grades into the Guanal. Cerro Caudal also overlies Guanal. Implied correlation between the Cocodrilo and the La Cabana and Salado fms (Castellanos et al 2003, Castellanos 2011).

Other age details or opinions: Includes recent fossils (Franco et al 1992). Overlies the Jaimanitas, so must be Upper Pleistocene and younger. Castellanos et al (2003) discussed La Cabana and Salada fms as Wisconsinan (uppermost Pleistocene , younger than 75ky).
Correlation: Correlates with Santa Isabel mbr of Cayo Piedras.

Supporting References: Castellanos et al 2003, Castellanos 2011, Rojas-Agramonte et al 2005,
Notes: The first Pleistocene terrace in the Sierra Maestra area (Rojas-Agramonte et al 2005), and the most widespread Quaternary unit in Cuba (Franco et al 1992). Includes Punta Monje and Tortuguilla mbrs.
Other age details or opinions: Late Pleistocene; not older than 1.75 or younger than 0.01 (Rojas-Agramonte et al 2005). Castellanos et al 2003 discussed a lower Upper Pleistocene deposition (interglacial Sangomonian, 75-125 ky), consistent with Castellanos 2011.
Correlation: Punta Monje and Tortuguilla mbrs laterally grade into each other.

Notes: Reef complex (Franco et al 1992)
Other age details or opinions: Middle Pleistocene (Franco et al 1992).
Correlation: Correlates with La Cabana in Western Cuba. Unconformably overlies the Canimar.

Notes: reef lmst deposits on Isla de la Juventud
Other age details or opinions: Upper Pliocene to Lower Pleistocene (Franco et al 1992). See also notes on the Vedado, a better constrained unit and possible equivalent.
Correlation: May be related to the Vedado fm (also in W Cuba); both are PlioPleistocene reef lm according to Franco et al 1992. The proposed equivalent in the East is the Rio Maya. Conformably overlies and laterally grades with the Guane. Also a lateral equivalent to Vedado. Unconformably overlies the Guines and Paso Real fms. Unconformably underlies the Cayo Piedras.

Notes: Reef complex (Franco et al 1992)
Other age details or opinions: Late Pliocene to early Pleistocene (Franco et al 1992, Cabrera Castellanos et al 2003). See also notes on the Vedado, a better constrained unit and possible equivalent.
Correlation: Could be eastern equivalent of Vedado and Punta del Este fms in west. Unconformably overlies Baracoa, Cabo Cruz, La Cruz, San Antonia, and Baitiquiri units. Unconformably overlain by undifferentiated Baracoa and Punta Monje and Tortuguilla mbrs of Jaimanitas. The Rio Maya overlies Yacabo mbr of Punta Imias fm (Franco et al 1992).

Notes: Informal; Franco et al 1992 considered the unit synonymous with Matanzas fm of Spencer 1984 and 1985 papers.
Other age details or opinions: Lower Pleistocene (Franco et al 1992). Lower age should be upper bound of El Abra mbr (Canimar fm) and upper age below the lower bound of Versalles, based on stratigraphic relationships.
Correlation: Unconformably overlies the El Abra mbr of the Canimar fm. Unconformably underlies the Versalles fm.

Supporting References: Vinola-Lopez and Rojas-Consuegra 2016; Diaz-Franco and Rojas-Consuegra 2009; Schweitzer et al 2006
Notes: Includes Abra and Maíca members. NW of Matanzas province
Other age details or opinions: Schweitzer et al 2006 present a log with undifferentiated Canimar in the upper half ot the Late Miocene, below the El Abra (approximately the age range of the Messinian). Franco et al 1992 speculate at a Late Pliocene to possible late Lower Pleistocene deposition. The El Abra contains reworked clasts from the Upper Cretaceous and Neogene, but the most likely age for a fossil fish from the unit is late Pliocene, during the maximal regression (Diaz-Franco and Rojas-Consuegra 2009). The authors do not assert confidence in any more specific age range for the fossil than Plio-Pleistocene, however. Vinola-Lopez and Rojas-Consuegra 2016  described another fish from the Canimar and cited the age as Pliocene based on the 2011 update to Franco et al Lexicon.
Correlation: El Abra and Maica mbrs laterally grade.

Notes: Reef complex (Franco et al 1992)
Other age details or opinions: Maurasse plotted the Vedado from the Early-Late Pliocene boundary through to just below the Plio-Pleist boundary, with an unmistakable unconformity below and questionable one above. Note that the Plio-Pleist boundary was set at 1.6 Ma then, not 2.58 as today. Franco et al. gave an age range of Upper Pliocene to Lower Pleistocene. The conformable relationship above the El Abra mbr of the Canimar would suggest a lower bound at the present Plio-Pleistocene boundary, 2.58 Ma.
Correlation: May be related to the Punta del Este fm (also in W Cuba); both are PlioPleistocene reef lm according to Franco et al 1992. The proposed equivalent in the East is the Rio Maya. Laterally grades into Cainimar, Guane and Punta del Este fms. Comformably overlies Canimar (undifferentiated part and the El Abra and Maica mbrs). Unconformably overlies Cojimar, Guines, and Paso Real. Unconformably underlies Cayo Piedras, Guanabo, and Villarroja.

Supporting References: Vinola-Lopez and Rojas-Consuegra 2016; Diaz-Franco and Rojas-Consuegra 2009; Schweitzer et al 2006
Other age details or opinions: Schweitzer et al 2006 present a log with undifferentiated Canimar in the upper half ot the Late Miocene, below the El Abra. Franco et al 1992 speculate at a Late Pliocene to possible late Lower Pleistocene deposition. The El Abra contains reworked clasts from the Upper Cretaceous and Neogene, but the most likely age for a fossil fish from the unit is late Pliocene, during the maximal regression (Diaz-Franco and Rojas-Consuegra 2009). The authors do not assert confidence in any more specific age range for the fossil than Plio-Pleistocene, however. Vinola-Lopez and Rojas-Consuegra 2016  described another fish from the Canimar and cited the age as Pliocene based on the 2011 update to Franco et al Lexicon.
Correlation: El Abra and Maica mbrs laterally grade.

Notes: Informal unit. Synonymous with the Salvador mbr of Ramon fm. Fossiliferous; sublittoral with some reefs.
Other age details or opinions: Upper Pliocene (Franco et al 1992)
Correlation: Bounded by unconformities; overlies Manzanillo.

Other age details or opinions: Late Miocene to earliest Pliocene (Franco et al 1992).
Correlation: Conformably overlies the Quintero mbr and underlies the Santiago mbr.
Other opinions on correlations: Woodring 1928 p. 61 seems to have correlated the La Cruz with the Bowden fm (Jamaica). See notes on the Bowden here, which suggest age is ca 3-4 Ma.

Notes: Redescribed in Franco 1980a
Other age details or opinions: latest Late Miocene to Lower Pliocene (Franco et al 1992). The lower bound must be younger than 16 Ma based on relationship above Maquey and San Antonio fms.
Correlation: Unconformably overlies Maquey, Sabaneta (Paleocene), and San Antonio fms. Unconformably underlies Maya River. Correlated with Bellamar, Júcaro, La Cruz (Mbar Tejar), Manzanillo and Punta Imías in Cuba and Bowden in Jamaica. Note that Manzanillo is much older according to Maurasse 1990, however.

Notes: Different unit from the Cabo Cruz. Lewis and Straczek 1955 USGS report pp. 272-275 gives fossil fauna lists. Includes Quintero, Tejar and Santiago mbrs.
Other age details or opinions: Late Miocene to Early Pliocene. The Quintero mbr is a basal conglomerate that lacks fossils and based on stratigraphic position is estimated at Middle-Late Miocene (Franco et al 1992). Thus, the fossiliferous portion is constrained to the upper 2 units. Pardo (2009) mentions the unit only briefly, noting it as upper Miocene.
Other opinions on correlations: Woodring 1928 p. 61 seems to have correlated the La Cruz with the Bowden fm (Jamaica). See notes on the Bowden here, which suggest age is ca 3-4 Ma.

Other age details or opinions: Early Pliocene (Franco et al 1992).
Correlation: Conformably overlies the Tejar mbr of La Cruz. Quaternary gravels above.
Other opinions on correlations: Woodring 1928 p. 61 seems to have correlated the La Cruz with the Bowden fm (Jamaica). See notes on the Bowden here, which suggest age is ca 3-4 Ma.

Notes: Very rich fauna of mollusks, echinoids, calcareous algae, foraminifera, and nannoplankton' according to Pardo.
Other age details or opinions: Late Miocene to Lower Pliocene (Pantelényi and Garcés 1988; Pardo 2009).
Correlation: Unconformably underlies Jaimanitas. Conformably overlies the Jagueyes.

Notes: Lagoonal to sublittoral. The name Punta Imías may be used to avoid confusion with the invalid Imías unit of Kozary 1954 (year of publication questionable). As with the [Rio] Jagueyes, however, Pardo prefers the unmodified version of the name (in this case, Imias).
Other age details or opinions: Cobielle et al (1977) discuss the unit and propose a Middle to Pliocene age. Forams place samples from Macambo in the Middle Miocene and samples closer to Yacabo date to the Upper Miocene. Otracodes from the same locality near Yacabo are less precise, with an age estimate ranging from Upper Miocene to Pleistocene. The authors cite oral correspondence with Iturralde-Vinent, who also found Pliocene evidence at the top of the Imias. Franco et al (1992) later changed the name (Imias to Punta Imias) and definition of the Imias, such that the Guardarraya was demoted from a fm and lumped into the Imias. Thus, Cobielle's estimate may apply to the Yacabo, while the Guardarraya may be older.
Correlation: Correlates with El Abra mbr of Canimar fm.

Other age details or opinions: Late Lower Pliocene (Franco et al 1992). Based on the correlation of the Imas with the El Abra (2.58-3.6 unit in this compilation), the Yacabo might extend into the Upper Pliocene, however.
Correlation: Guardarraya (lower mbr) grades up into Yacabo (upper mbr).

Notes: Partially synonymous with Matanzas grp and Canímar (P.J.Bermúdez, 195O), Cojímar (C.Ducloz, 1963), Cojímar (P.J.Bermúdez, 1967), and Capas de Gypsina (A. de la Torre, 1966) fms. Sub- to infra- littoral.
Other age details or opinions: Franco et al list the age as Late Miocene.
Correlation: Unconformably overlies Caobas and Guines. Unconformably underlies Vedado and the undifferentiated part of Canimar.

Notes: Partially synonymous with Matanzas grp and Canímar (P.J.Bermúdez, 195O), Cojímar (C.Ducloz, 1963), Cojímar (P.J.Bermúdez, 1967), and Capas de Gypsina (A. de la Torre, 1966) fms. Sub- to infra- littoral.
Other age details or opinions: Franco et al list the age as Late Miocene.

Notes: Partially synonymous with Matanzas grp and Canímar (P.J.Bermúdez, 195O), Cojímar (C.Ducloz, 1963), Cojímar (P.J.Bermúdez, 1967), and Capas de Gypsina (A. de la Torre, 1966) fms. Sub- to infra- littoral.
Other age details or opinions: Franco et al. estimated the age at Late Miocene to lower Pliocene. Schweitzer et al 2006 plot the El Maiz from slightly below the Middle-Late Miocene boundary (ca 11.5 Ma) to the end of the Late Miocene (ca 5.3 Ma), i.e. not extending into the Pliocene.

late Middle to Late Miocene (Franco et al 1992). Pardo (2009) aggrees, giving an age of middle to upper Miocene, possibly up to the Pliocene. In this correlation, 'late Middle' is estimated as the Langhian-Serravallian boundary, 13.82 Ma.
Correlation: Correlates with Loma Triana

Notes: sublittoral
Other age details or opinions: Late Miocene (Franco et al 1992).
Correlation: Correlates with lower Baracoa, Juracaro, La Cruz and Manzanillo

Notes: Iturradle-Vinent et al 1996 claimed there were no molluscs, but there were marine vertebrate fossils. However, Paredo 2009 noted 'very abundant mollusks' as well as corals.
Other age details or opinions: Iturralde-Vinent 1968 plotted lower boundary in late Aquitatnian, with a top surface unconformity at the Middle-Upper Miocene boundary. Iturralde-Vinent 1969 stated the age as Middle Miocene, upper M2 through M5, which we infer as 10-15 Ma. Maurasse 1990 plotted a section in South Central Cuba (Zaza) spanning the entire Miocene, and a section in Central Cuba (platform) spanning the Late Miocene through entire Pliocene. Franco et al 1992 estimated the age as upper Lower Miocene to lower Late Miocene, which agrees well with Iturralde-Vinent's general range. Iturralde-Vinent et al 1996 discuss the Guines as Lower-Middle Miocene. Schweitzer et al 2006 present a log with the Guines from ca 10-16 Ma. Pardo plotted the Guines in a correlative log as spanning the entire Miocene in the Northern Coast, but only Middle-Upper Miocene in the Southern basins.
Correlation: The Guines/Vasquez fms overly the Los Arabos fm at an unconformity. The Los Arabos and Vasquez fms don't contain macrofossils. Pardo considers the Rosario and Cojimar fms to be partial equivalents to the Guines.

Notes: Demoted from fm to mbr status
Other age details or opinions: Late Miocene to Lower Pliocene (Franco et al 1992).
Correlation: Guardarraya (lower mbr) grades up into Yacabo (upper mbr).

Other age details or opinions: Franco et al describe age as upper Middle to lower Late Miocene. In this correlation, these vaugue estimates are equated to the Langhian-Serrravallian and Tortonian-Messinian boundaries, respectively.
Correlation: Correlates with Cabo Cruz

Other age details or opinions: Late Miocene (Franco et al 1992). The upper date should be less than that of the undifferentiated part, based on their stratigraphic relationship. The lower date should be at least as old as the minimum age of the Manzanillo, which is laterally equivalent at least in part. Indeed, the younger bound of the Manzanillo may be a good correlate to the top of the El Abra, given that the two laterally grade into one another.
Correlation: Correlates with Loma Triana. Laterally grades into Manzanillo fm. Upper contact is graded with undifferentiated Cabo Cruz fm.

Supporting References: Pardo 2009; Iturralde-Vinent and MacPhee 1999; Maurasse 1990 plate 5a
Notes: Outcrops only in the Cauto basin, Eastern Cuba (Iturralde-Vinent and MacPhee 1999)
Other age details or opinions: Lower two-thirds of Middle Miocene (Maurasse 1990), which on today's chronostratigraphic scale might be ca 13 Ma. Franco et al. 1992 gave a conflicting range of upper Late Miocene to Lower Pliocene. Franco et al 1992 also observed that the Late Miocene Rolanda mbr of Cabo Cruz grades laterally with the Manzanillo, which would make these two units equivalent at least in part. The Rolanda extends back only to ca 11.6 Ma, which would force a younger bound to the Manzanillo than Maurasse's estimate. Iturralde-Vinent and MacPhee 1999 agree with a Late Miocene minimum age; they plot the Manzanillo in a log section from ca 9-14 Ma. Pardo 2009 gives a generous range of middle Miocene to Pliocene.
Correlation: Underlies La Cruz or Imias depending on section (Maurasse 1990). Pardo noted that the Manzanillo unconformably overlies the San Luis and Cobre fms (Eocene), and in section placed the Manzanillo above the Limones.

Notes: Franco et al 1992 modified the name to be Río Jagüeyes because they considered the Jagüeyes (Brönnimann and Pardo 1954) as an invalid homonym. However, Pardo (2009) retains the name Jagüeyes.
Other age details or opinions: Middle Miocene, maybe extending a bit farther on either boundary (Franco et al 1992). Pardo (2009) restricted the age range to be entirely middle Miocene.
Correlation: Laterally grades into Paso Real fm. Unconformably overlies the Camazan, Bitiri, and Vigia fms.

Notes: Contains one defined mbr. Synonymous in part with the Cabo Cruz, Cojimar, and Imias. There is also a San Antonio fm in Mexico, but there are no reported fossils there.
Other age details or opinions: Synonymies and correlations suggest a Middle Miocene age.
Correlation: Correlates with Real Paso fm.

Notes: Synonymous with Guines (Iturralde-Vinent 1968). Cooper 1979 lists brachs from this fm.
Other age details or opinions: Middle Miocene (Franco et al 1992). This age agrees well with the Habana-Matanzas Basin section of Guines included in Schweitzer et al 2006, although Pardo 2009 plotted the Guines almost entirely as Upper Miocene in the Habana-Matanzas basin. As a compromise, the unit is placed in the Serravallian (upper Middle Miocene) in this compilation.

Notes: Not to be confused with Punta Imías
Other age details or opinions: Franco et al considered the name invalid and hence renamed a different unit the Punta Imias to avoid confusion. Maurasse 1990 plate 5a plotted the unit across the Mid-Late Miocene boundary, only in SE Cuba (Baracoa Purial), and overlying the Manzanillo unconformably. Schweitzer et al 2006 report invertebrates from the unit, at Baitiquiri, and log the sandy marls from ca 12.5 to 18 Ma in fig 2.
Franco et al give date range of upper Lower to lower Middle Miocene. The specific ages used here for those vague estimates are the same as for the Cojimar fm, based on stratigraphic correlation.
Correlation: Correlates with Cojimar and San Antonio

Supporting References: Pardo 2009, Schweitzer et al 2006, Mederos 1987, Maurasse 1990 plate 5a
Notes: Franco et al 1992 considered synonymous with Bejucal, Cangrejeras, and Capellanias, and inferred the environment to be deep infralittoral to upper slope of shelf. Maurasse noted the unit was a white and yellow limestone cropping out only in Western Cuba Bahia Honda.
Other age details or opinions: Late Aquitanian through the Burdigalian in Iturralde-Vinent 1968. Lower-Middle Miocene according to Mederos 1987. Middle Miocene in Maurasse 1990 plate 5a. Upper Lower to lower Middle Miocene in Franco et al 1992, zones Globorotalia fohsi s.l. and Globigerinoides sicanus-Globigerinatella insueta. Schweitzer et al 2006 plot Cojimar in log section without clear boundaries, but in the region of the lower Middle Miocene and possibly as old as the latest Early Miocene (M4, ca 16.5 Ma). Pardo determines the age as middle Miocene (G fohsi zone) based on dense foram data.
Correlation: Underlies local Guines, overlies Colon (Maurasse 1990), both at conformable contacts (Franco et al 1992). Iturralde-Vinent 1968 throught that the top contact was an unconformity, however. The Cojimar meets the Guines again laterally. Pardo places the Cojimar conformably above the Jaruco and Husillo, and again as a partial lateral equivalent to the Guines. Pardo considers the Rosario a partial equivalent to the Cojimar.

Supporting References: Redescribed in G. L. Franco (1976) in: Jakus, 1983.
Notes: Restricted marine; contains Ostracodes
Other age details or opinions: Franco et al (1992) state an age of upper Lower Miocene to lower Middle Miocene.
Correlation: Conformably ('concordantemente') overlies the Maquey and unconformity overlies Saint Louis fm. Underlies Jamaica and Rio Maya, at unconformities.

Notes: Franco et al 1992 modified the name from Rosario to Santa María del Rosario because they considered the Rosario (Hatten and Meyerhoff 1956) an invalid homonym. However, as in other units with names that Franco revised, Pardo retains the original (short) version, e.g. Rosario.
Other age details or opinions: Franco et al (1992) estimate the age as upper Lower to lower Middle Miocene. Pardo (2009) considered the unit middle Miocene, which matches the constraints from correlative ages. That is, the Rosario overlies the Husillo, which has an upper bound of 16 Ma in this compilation.
Correlation: Pardo described the Rosario as a partial equivalent to the Guines, Cojimar, and Cangrejeras fms. The Rosario is unconformable over the Husillo and older rocks.

Other age details or opinions: Early Miocene according to Franco et al (1992). Middle Miocene according to Pardo (2009). Here, the top bound is placed at the Langhian-Serravallian boundary as a compromise between the two schemes. The conformable relationship above the Maquey places a lower bound at 18 Ma in this compilation.
Correlation: Conformably overlies the Maquey (Pardo 2009).

Supporting References: Vinola-Lopez and Rojas-Consuegra 2016; Franco et al 1992; Maurasse 1990 plate 5a
Notes: Only occurs in Western Cuba Bahia Honda
Other age details or opinions: Underlies Cojimar, overlies Tinguaro, both uncomforably (Iturralde-vinent 1968, Maurasse 1990). Upper Oligocene to upper part of Lower Miocene (Fraco et al 1992), an age range cited in Vinola-Lopez and Rojas-Consuegra 2016. However, recent work on the Husillo (a synonym) does not place the lower boundary as old as the Oligo-Miocene boundary, but rather at ca 20 Ma. See discussion of Husillo fm elsewhere in this correlation. The upper boundary may be constrained at the maximum age of the overlying Cojimar.
Correlation: Equivalent to Husillo fm (Maurasse 1990, Franco et al 1992)

Notes: This name has been applied to different units that were synonymized: Husillo (Seiglie 1960) is the Jaruco, and Husillo (Bronnimann and rigassi 1963) is the Colon.
Other age details or opinions: Bronnimann and Rigassi 1963 originally stated the age as Lower Miocene; their unit was synonymized with the Colon, which according to this compilation would set the age as Upper Oligocene to upper part of Lower Miocene (Fraco et al 1992, Vinola-Lopez and Rojas-Consuegra 2016). Seiglie 1960's Husillo was synonymized with the Jaruco, for which Franco et al 1992 estimated the same age range. However, Schweitzer et al 2006 considered the Husillo a valid unit and did not extend it as far as the Oligo-Miocene boundary; oldest age was 16-20 Ma in Fig 2, for the Jabana-Matanzas basin. Pardo (2009) uses forams to justify a lower Miocene age and considers the equivalent Jaruco to be a valid unit.
Correlation: Equivalent to Colon fm (Maurasse 1990). Pardo (2009) describes the relationship as conformable over the Guanajay and Tinguaro fms.

Notes: The so-called Paso Real in Costa Rica is Pliocene, but in Cuba is Miocene.
Other age details or opinions: The Lagunitas (ca 17-19 Ma) may partially equate to the Paso Real (Iturralde-Vinent 1969, 1987). In a completely different interpretation, Maurasse 1990 plotted it entirely as late Oligocene, and only in South Central Cuba. Pardo (2009) agreed with Iturralde-Vinent's view, suggesting a lower to middle Miocene age. The unit is a wedge, such that it tapers out over the course of the Middle Miocene.
Correlation: Pardo plotted the Paso Real below the Guines and above the Guanajay (Oligocene).

Supporting References: MacPhee and Iturralde-Vinent 1994, MacPhee et al 2003
Other age details or opinions: MacPhee and Iturralde-Vinent 1994 reported a Xenarthra fossil from the fm and gave an age of 17.5-18.5 Ma. They describe microfossil evidence that it cannot extend quite as far back as the Oligo-Miocene boundary, but probably is N6-N7, Burdigalian, ca 16.9-19 Ma.
Correlation: Correlation with the coastal onlap event of Haq et al 1987 is highly likely' (MacPhee and Iturralde-Vinent 1994), which would make the age 18.5-17.5 Ma. The Lagunitas may partially equate to the Paso Real, Arabos, Rosario, and Magantilla fms (Iturralde-Vinent 1969, 1987).

Notes: Includes Cilindro mbr (Late Oligocene to Lower Miocene, although the top bound is very uncertain), Gobernadora, and Vega Grande (latest Oligocene to Lower Miocene). Name from Sierra del Maquey, in reference to the shells used by hermit crabs there (Lewis & Straczek 1955 USGS survey, p. 188).
Other age details or opinions: Oligocene to Early Miocene, authors agree. The Vega Grande mbr is the youngest and so is the most likely mbr to be restricted to the Miocene, but the VG lower boundary could still fall below the Oligo-Mio transition. Pardo plots the lower bound of the Maguey near the Rupelian-Chattian boundary (27.8 Ma).
Correlation: Iturralde-Vinent 2001 note similarity in lithology and age among Maquey, La Toca (DR) and Thomonde (DR) fms. The Thomonde ranges from Late Miocene to earliest Pliocene in Saint Marc area (Maurrasse 1982).
Other opinions on correlations: Cilindro mbr is basal and topped by an unconformity. Gobernadora, the middle unit, grades into overlying Vega Grande mbr.

Other age details or opinions: Lower terrace has average Uranium-based age of 129 ka, correlated with terrace I on Curacao and terrace III on Barbados (Schubert and Szabo 1978). Inferring a Sangamonian deposition, this could indicate an age range within 80-140 ka.
See age details for constituent units.

Fouke et al 1996 plot subunit 1 in section from the start of the Langhian until ca 13 Ma, when athe area was subaerially exposed. Maurasse 1990 plate 5b considers the unit almost exclusively Piacenzian, which was then defined as 1.6-3.4 Ma.

Fouke et al 1996 derived Sr age estimate of 5.0-5.2 from unaltered fossils in subunit 2, and younger dates from altered fossils. Fouke et al 1996 plot subunit 1 in section across the entire Late Miocene and Pliocene. At the time of writing, the Mid-Late Miocene boundary was set at ca 10 Ma and the Mio-Pliocene boundary was set at ca 1.6 Ma.

Fouke et al 1996 derived Sr age estimate of 15.6 from unaltered fossils in subunit 1, and younger dates from altered fossils. They also use foram stratigraphy to estimate the age range as 15.2-16.2 for lithofacies 1-3; lithofacies 4 extends into the Serravallian. This is younger than the early estimates of an Eo-Oligocene age based on offshore wells (Curet 1992), but not as young as Maurasse's 1990 plate 5b estimate of Late Miocene (and also including the latest Serravallian).

Cooke et al 1943 combined part of Cape May and Pensauken, considering both Sangamonian. Richards 1945 strongly disagreed, stating thate Cape May was late Pleistocene but Pensauken was mid-Pleistocene at youngest. The Pennsylvania geological survey map in 1960 classified the Pensauken as Illinoian. Owens and Denny 1979 extended the unit to DE and MD and changed the age estimate from early Pleistocene to Miocene. Conant 1990 considered the Pensauken to be late Miocene in age. Pazzaglia 1993 described the Pensauken lithology in detail and correlated it with the upper Bethany through Beaverdam fms, Pliocene. Pazzaglia and Gardner 1993 petrographically correlated the unit with late Pliocene and early Pleistocene marine deposits.
Correlation: Underlies Cape May (late Pleistocene) unconformably. Overlies Bridgeton (Miocene), which overlies the Beacon Hill; authors debate whether or not this sequence is graded.

Other age details or opinions: Late Pliocene-Pleistocene, but plotted as the very latest Piacenzian plus the Calabrian, Emilian, Sicilian, and Milazzian.
Correlation: Overlies the Arroyo Blanco.

Notes: Not to be confused with Oligocene unit of same name in Cuba. Outcrops at edge of basin, mixed gypsum, shallow-marine siliciclastics and carbonates.
Other age details or opinions: Mostly Lower Pliocene, but surface rocks of the Arroyo Blanco and Arroyo Seco fms are Upper Miocene-Lower Pliocene according to multiple studies, reviewed in Mann et al 1999. Questionably assigned to N17-19, which corresponds to ca 8.3-4.0 Ma; conflictingly, placed in the upper Zanclean through Piacenzian (then an upper bound of 1.65 Ma).

Notes: Occurs in Charco Largo-1 well.
Other age details or opinions: Ostracodes in well section indicate mid Pliocene to Holocene. Lower Pliocene
Correlation: Equivalent to Arroyo Blanco. Overlain by Jimani fm (terrestrial). Overlies the Angostura fm (largely halite).

Other age details or opinions: Tentatively NN18 (Lower Pliocene), which has a range of ca 1.9-2.5 Ma (Berggren et al 1995). However, Mann et al update previous chornostratigraphic logs to place the unit as entirely Zanclean (then defined as 5.2-3.5 Ma).
Correlation: Overlies the Trinchera and underlies the Arroyo Blanco in the NE Enriquillo basin surface.

Other age details or opinions: McNeill et al 2012 combined micropaleo, paleomag, and Sr isotopes to develop a strat framework and constrain fm ages
Correlation: Overlies the Gurabo fm

Other age details or opinions: McNeill et al 2012 combined micropaleo, paleomag, and Sr isotopes to develop a strat framework and constrain fm ages.
Well data suggest 'Upper Miocene to basal Pliocene' age. latest-Middle Miocene to earliest Pliocene
Correlation: In places, comforambly overlain by Arroyo Blanco and Las Salinas.

The Prairie Frm (135-60 Ka) (Mateo 2005; Otvos 2005, 2009; Shen et al 2008); Biloxi Frm (132-116 Ka) (Otvos 2005, 2009, 2013); and Gulfport Frm (132-118 Ka) (Otvos 2013) are not valid formations according to the Florida Geological Survey (Means, pers comm 2013). Huddlestun (pers comm 2013) also indicated the Biloxi Frm of Otvos is present in the coastal area as far east as St. George Island and is in the same stratigraphic position as the Satilla Frm of GA. Notes: Part of Beaumont group. Beaumont is subdivided in LA. Oberlin is below Eunice; they were formerly the Bentley and Montgomery units.

The older bound could reasonably be set at the base of the Calabrian, given that the Pleistocene definition changed later to extend as far back as the Gelasian.
Correlation: Overlies Foley fm

Notes: Part of Fleming Group. A part of the Lagarto unit was lumped into the Cuero fm; the other Lagarto (after Dumble) was lumped into the Goliad (which was considered Pliocene at the time) (Weeks 1945).

Notes: Members in descending order are Blounts Creek, Castor Creek, Williamson Creek, Dough Hills, Carnahan Bayou, Lena. Other age details or opinions: Middle Miocene (Quinn 1952)
Foram composition led Richards 1939 to correlate Pleistocene last interglacial Texas, e.g. Beaumont, to the Port Hudson in LA and MS.

Notes: The Catahoula outcrops in Mexico, but no one has reported fossils there. The name Catahoula replaced Grand Gulf Sandstone. Also see unpublished USGS staff note quoted in Geolex: 'In absence of clearly definable and correlatable litho- or biostratigraphic horizons to bracket them, application of formation names, previously assigned to paralic-alluvial intervals (Oligocene to Miocene Catahoula Formation, Miocene Hattiesburg and Pascagoula Formations, and Pliocene Graham Ferry Formation; Brown and others, 1944) is unacceptable in MS. In intervals for which a Miocene or Pliocene age cannot be established, the term "undifferentiated Neogene clastics" is recommended. Whenever applicable, the names Pascagoula and Graham Ferry Members of Pensacola Formation are now used. Author follows usage of Otvos (1994).'
Correlation: The unit (or at least the tuff component) underlies Oakville (or its Fleming equivalent) and overlies (Oligocene) Frio or Vicksburg fms.

Notes: Variously placed as the lowest member of the Yorktown (Gibson 1971, but removed after deciding the Yorktown is wholly Pliocene) or upper part of St Mary's (where it was called the Virginia St Marys beds until Ward and Blackwelder 1980 renamed it the Eastover fm).
Other age details or opinions: Upper part radiometric data was 6.46 +/- 0.15 Ma (Blackwelder and Ward 1976, who also found 4.4 +/0 0.2 K/Ar date on lower Yorktown beds). It is unclear whether discussion implies that the unit is equivalent to Cintronelle, Bryn Mawr, and Beach Hill, or is the end of that depositional series. Note that the many lithofacies of the hotly debated Citronelle seem to be mostly Pliocene (2.6-3.3 Ma in this compilation). The Bryn Mawr is Pliocene (Lewis 1881). The Beacon Hill gravel is Miocene in GeoLex. Woodworth et al 1934 mention a Pleistocene horse fossil found in what had previously been considered Miocene. At the time of writing, the Plio-Pleistocene boundary would have been at 1.6 Ma.
Correlation: Underlies Dukes boulder bed at Gay Head Cliffs fold (Woodworth et al 1934).

Notes: Kaye 1983 described the unit and tentatively assigned it to late Miocene and early Pliocene age based on palynology.

Notes: Outcrops on Martha's vineyard
Other age details or opinions: Early Pliocene according to Kaye 1983. Probably constrained to the later part of the Early Pliocene based on the upper boundary of the unit below.

The nomenclature of Yarmouthian and Kansan has been abandoned; the whole of that timeline is now lumped into the  Pre-Illinoian, 0.2-2.5 Ma. Notes: USGS considers the unit to be Wisconsinan based on Fuller's 1905 description.
Correlation: Overlies Gardiners Clay

Notes: Veatch thought the unit was Kansan, but that chronological unit is abandoned because its reference point was found to vary by 2 Ma at different places. The USGS considers the Moshup Till member of the Jameco as Pleistocene.
Correlation: Underlies Sankaty beds and unconformably overlies putative Pensauken.

Supporting References: Oldale and Colman 1992, Sanders and Merguerian 1994
Notes: Interglacial deposit on Fishers Island, NY.

However, Sanders and Merguerian 1994 placed these units as Yarmouthian and Kansan, respectively. The nomenclature of Yarmouthian and Kansan has been abandoned; the whole of that timeline is now lumped into the  Pre-Illinoian, 0.2-2.5 Ma. The same authors isotopically dated fossils from the Sankaty Sand, which they correlate with the Montauk till, 120-140 ka.

Notes: Abundantly fossiliferous, with mollusks and ostracods. From Sankaty Head, Nantucket Island.
Other age details or opinions: Odale and Colman 1992 date shells from the unit. A radiocarbon age of 32 ka from the lower unit came from a recrystallized and therefore unreliable shell. Reliable ages are a Sr-Th age of 133 ka from a coral in the upper unit and an Ar age of 120-140 ka for shells from both units. The authors assign a Sangamonian age and correlat ethe unit with the Montauk Till.

The USGS considered the Herod to be Wisconsinan, but see discussion of the entire Manhasset Formation as Kansan, and note that the Herod underlies the Montauk. The nomenclature of Yarmouthian and Kansan has been abandoned; the whole of that timeline is now lumped into the  Pre-Illinoian, 0.2-2.5 Ma.

Petroleum geologists assigned a Late Pleistocene age, but more recent work (Aguilera-Martinez et al 2003) suggested a Plio-Pleistocene age. The older date more closely matches original descriptions as Late Miocene.

Supporting References: Perez Rincon 1959, Léxico estratigráfico de México
Other age details or opinions: Perez Rincon 1959 and other early workers asserted a Middle Miocene age. However, petroleum geologists assigned an Upper Pliocene-Lower Pleistocene age based on sequence stratigraphy. The Mexican lexicon reviews many conflicting age estimates, ranging from Middle Miocene to Pleistocene. An upper age of Pleistocene is consistent with a graded contact into the overlying Cedral. Aguilera-Martinez (2003) suggested a Pliocene age, which adds evidence that this is the lower bound. The older bound used in this compilation is the midpoint of the Piacenzian. (Note that the Plio-Pleistocene boundary would have been younger (ca 1.6 Ma) at the time of writing, however, but not the time of review by the Mexican lexicon.)
Correlation: Overlies the Filisola or Concepcion fms. Conformably underlies the Cedral. Unconformably underlies the Agueguexquite locally, which causes contradiction with the new, Miocene age dates of the Agueguexquite. Local outcrops of the Paraje Solo may equivalent to the Agueguequite, and where they are not in contact the ages may differ.

Other age details or opinions: Early workers agreed upon a Pliocene age, but Hay (1926 in Lopez-Ramos 1979) reports a mastodon. Therefore, the unit presumably includes Pleistocene deposition as well. Overlies Belem fm, which is Late Pliocene or younger, so perhaps the Tres Puentes is latest Pliocene onward or entirely Pleistocene. The older bound used in this compilation is the midpoint of the Piacenzian. (Note that the Plio-Pleistocene boundary would have been younger at the time of writing, however, but not the time of review by the Mexican lexicon.)
Correlation: The Tres Puentes unit may correlate with the Cedral; it overlies the Upper Belem.

Other age details or opinions: Late Pliocene (Narvaez-rodriguez et al 2008 modification of earlier work). However, earlier workers have proposed Middle-Late Miocene, Late Miocene, or Late Miocene-Pliocene ages, as reviewed in the Mexican lexicon. The older bound used in this compilation is the midpoint of the Piacenzian, the same as that of the proposed correlate unit, the Tres Puentes.
Correlation: Late Pliocene units, in ascending order, are Encajonado, Zargazal, and Belem fms. These seem to grade into one another in log section. Lopez-Ramos 1979 suggested this unit as yet another equivalent to the Agueguexquite (there are many proposed equivalents to this long-ranging unit).

Other age details or opinions: Top grades into Plio-Pleistocene boundary lmst. Revised ages place the unit as Late Miocene to Pliocene, as reviewed in the Mexican lexicon.
Correlation: Lower boundary is an unconformity over the Chichén Itzá fm (Paleogene-Eocene). Grades into the Bacalar fm in Quintana Roo.

Other age details or opinions: Late Pliocene (Narvaez-rodriguez et al 2008 modification of earlier work). The Mexican geology lexicon cites earlier work (Campbell in Lopez Ramos 1979) that assigned a Middle Miocene age, however, and notes Gibson's (1936) correlation of the Encajonado with the Agueguexquite (Late Miocene in this compilation).
Correlation: Late Pliocene units, in ascending order, are Encajonado, Zargazal, and Belem fms. These seem to grade into one another in log section.

Other age details or opinions: The Mexican stratigraphic lexicon reviews opinion based on correlation that the age is upper Miocene or Pliocene. That is, the unit is younger than the Bacalar and could range up to the Pleistocene.
Correlation: Comformably overlies the Bacalar and is subadjacent to the Carillo Puerto fm.

Other age details or opinions: Late Pliocene (Narvaez-Rodriguez et al 2008 modification of earlier work). As with the Encajonado, however, the Mexican geology lexicon cites earlier work (in Lopez Ramos 1979) that assigned a Middle Miocene age. Similarly, the lexicon notes Gibson's (1936) correlation of the Zargazal with the Agueguexquite (Late Miocene in this compilation). Elsewhere the lexicon correlates the Paraje Solo with the Zargazal, and the Paraje Solo in this compilation is considered Late Plioce to early Pleistocene, supporting Narvaez-Rodriguez et al.
Correlation: Late Pliocene units, in ascending order, are Encajonado, Zargazal, and Belem fms. These seem to grade into one another in log section. Gibson (1936) thought that the unit correlates with the Aguequexquite in Veracruz to Chiapas.

Other age details or opinions: Authors have speculated at many different ages for the unit, from middle Miocene to middle Pliocene. For instance, Herbert 2004 assumes and Early to middle Pliocene age. The Mexican lexicon constrains it to Pliocene, citing faunal evidence; a Pliocene age fits with the stratigraphic relationship inbetween the Paraje Solo and Cedral. The Cuba lexicon (Franco et al 1992) correlates the unit at a similar age (3-4 Ma). However, Pineda-Salgado et al (2016) review earlier work and provide the first isotopic dates, which rebuke earlier agreement on a Pliocene age. Nanoplankton from one site place the unit from the upper part of the Middle through the lower part of the Late Miocene (NN7-NN9). Stontrium samples from 3 sites give dates of 15.99 + 0.78 / - 1.31 Ma, 8.87 + 1.77 / - 2.26 Ma and 6.87+ 2.16 / - 0.88 Ma. These dates are more precise than the forams, which give a broad range of Miocene-Pliocene. If deposition was indeed limited to the Miocene, then the ages of the Cedral and Paraje Solo may be far wrong.
Other opinions on correlations: Franco et al 1992, discussing Cuban stratigraphy, references this fm as a partial correlate to the Caloosahatchee, Las Matas, Mao, Hinche, Bowden and Manchioneal. That would constrain the age very approximately to 3-4 Ma.

Other age details or opinions: Correlation provides vague or conflicting age estimates, but recent authors agree on a Pliocene age (see Mexican lexicon review). Thus, this work infers the age as that of a Pliocene, correlated unit, the Goliad.
Correlation: Top and bottom are unconformities. The Reynosa overlies the Lagarto and Catahoula formations. Correlates with Citronelle in the US and with Sabinas (terrestrial) and Goliad in Mexico, as reviewed in the Mexican lexicon. Note that in this compilation, the Goliad is older than the Citronelle. Furthermore, a part of the Lagarto unit was lumped into the Cuero fm; the other Lagarto (after Dumble) was lumped into the Goliad (which was considered Pliocene at the time) (Weeks 1945).

Other age details or opinions: According to Narvaez-Rodriguez et al (2008), the top is the Plio-Pleistocene boundary. Well drills indicate a haiatus from 4.2-5.5 Ma, if not longer in each direction, so the boundary between upper and lower subunits is presumably an unconformity. Stratigraphic parasequences seem to indicate a large regression at 9.2 Ma (coincidentally, the transgression at 10.5 agrees with the date estimated for Cuba), which could be the boundary between the Encarnacion and Amate formations based on their lithological transition from sandstone to shale (Narvaez-Rodriguez et al 2008). Islas-Tenorio et al (2004) mapped the unit conformably overlying the Macuspana fm, which is best estimated as early Miocene; there is a 3 Ma gap between their age ranges. The Mexican lexicon cites the map, but then uses older literature to suggest a Lower Miocene age for the Amate; this opinion is probably wrong.

According to Narvaez-Rodriguez et al (2008), the top is the Plio-Pleistocene boundary. Well drills indicate a haiatus from 4.2-5.5 Ma, if not longer in each direction, so the bottom boundary is presumably an unconformity.

Notes: There is an upper and lower unit, named the Superior and Inferior. The Mexican lexicon implies that some of the confusion over the age of the Concepcion may be due to confusion about where the boundary between the units occur.
Other age details or opinions: Every age range from Early Miocene to middle Pliocene has been suggested for the Concepcion, as reviewed in Pineda-Salgado et al 2015. Similarly, it has been correlated with the Tuxpan (Early Miocene here) and the Amate (Late Miocene-Pliocene here). A Late Miocene age seems likely given the relationship as overlying the probably Middle Miocene Encanto fm, a guess corroborated by Ayala's mollusk faunal analysis (2003). The lower bound is based on that of the Amate in this compilation.

Stratigraphic parasequences seem to indicate a large regression at 9.2 Ma (coincidentally, the transgression at 10.5 agrees with the date estimated for Cuba), which could be the boundary between the Encarnacion and Amate formations based on their lithological transition from sandstone to shale (Narvaez-Rodriguez et al 2008).

Mexican lexicon lists the age as Middle Miocene. However, as with many other units, it is difficult to reconcile the correlations with the ages: some think all the units are an epoch younger than in other frameworks. This compilation seeks a parsimonious correlation, and puts the Filisola as Late Miocene. This allows partial equivalency with the Concepcion (which the Filisola overlies), while respecting that no authors suggest the Filisola is Pliocene.
Correlation: Conformably overlies the Upper Concepcion fm. Top is similar to the Paraje Solo (difficult to translate whether the two are a lateral or vertical contact).

Notes: Cretaceous bivalves occur as reworked clasts.
Other age details or opinions: According to Galloway (1999), Oakville is lower Miocene and perhaps through P22 of upper Oligocene. Barnes' geologic maps for the Geologic atlas of Texas indicate a Miocene age. Correlation places the unit in the middle of the Miocene. The Mexican lexicon reviews foram dates that place the unit as early Late Miocene, or possibly into the Middle Miocene. A Lower Miocene age is given here for Texas, and lower Upper Miocene (Tortonian) age for Mexico.
Correlation: Overlies Catahoula fm; underlies Fleming fm by some definitions and is analagous in others.

Other age details or opinions: Stratigraphic parasequences seem to indicate a large regression at 9.2 Ma (coincidentally, the transgression at 10.5 agrees with the date estimated for Cuba), which could be the boundary between the Encarnacion and Amate formations based on their lithological transition from sandstone to shale (Narvaez-Rodriguez et al 2008).

Butterlin (1958) proposed equivalency between the Bacalar and the 'White marls' of Belize and speculated at a middle or late Miocene age. The marls mentioned were probably part of the Louisville fm, which is now an unofficial unit and part of the Red Bank formation (King 2003). The Red Bank was deposited in an early middle Miocene transgression, which has not been dated, but may correspond to one of the global and Caribbean sea level rises at ca 11 and 17 Ma (Galloway 1989).

Middle Miocene, according to the most recent maps (Miranda 1982 in Aguilera-Martinez et al 2003) reviewed in the Mexican lexicon. This agrees with the range set by correlation, 9.2-17.3 Ma (in this compilation) for upper and lower bounds of vertically adjacent units.
Correlation: Underlies the Lower Concepcion fm and overlies the Deposito fm.

Supporting References: Vega et al 2009, Martinez-Ortiz et al 2017, Narvaez-Rodriguez et al 2008
Other age details or opinions: Vega et al (2009) dated a sample from the formation and derived an age estimate of 19.5-20.5 Ma. Narvaez-Rodriguez et al 2008 plot the unit extending from the Lower through the Middle Miocene, however. By interpretation of their sequence stratigraphy, the top boundary may align with the regression at ca 12.5 Ma. Martinez-Ortiz et al (2017) treat the Macuspana fm as an early Miocene equivalent of the Tulija.
